contactinfoForm.phone.warning: Enter a phone number that contains 10 digits.
contactinfoPage.intro: We do not follow up with everyone who submits a report. We will only contact you to confirm your report or if we need more information.
contactinfoPage.skipInfo: You can skip this step to report anonymously.
contactinfoPage.title: Enter your contact details
covid19.protect.list1: Beware of unsolicited emails, phone calls or texts, especially related to COVID-19.
covid19.protect.list2: Do not click on any suspicious links or attachments in emails or texts.
covid19.protect.list3: Do not be pressured into providing personal information or money
covid19.protect.list4: Follow up with individuals, companies or charities using verified contact information that you find on their official website
covid19.protect.list5: Make sure you have anti-virus software installed and keep your operating system up to date.
covid19.report: If you have been the victim of fraud or cybercrime, including COVID-19 scams and cyber threats, contact your local police and report online through this tool.
covid19.resources: More resources to keep you safe during COVID-19
covid19.text1: As COVID-19 continues to spread, criminals are exploiting the health crisis to facilitate fraud and cybercrime. They are trying to profit from people’s fear and reliance on technology. Canadians should be cautious <0>of potential COVID-19 scams and other cyber threats involving websites, emails, texts and calls.</0>
covid19.title: COVID-19 cybercrime and fraud
default.hasValidationErrors: Please fix the errors on this page.

howDidItStartPage.intro: Anyone can experience a scam or computer crime. Criminals use a number of techniques to get what they want.
howDidItStartPage.nextPage: Next: When did the incident happen?
howDidItStartPage.tip: If it happens again in the future, avoid engaging with the suspect when possible.
howDidItStartPage.title: How did the incident start?
howDidTheyReachYou.question: How did the suspect reach you?
howDidTheyReachYou.reminder: Select all the ways they used to communicate with you.
howDidTheyReachYouLabel.hint1: Enter the suspect’s email address(es) or leave this blank if you don’t know.
howDidTheyReachYouLabel.hint2: Enter the suspect’s phone number(s) as listed on call display or leave this blank if you don’t know.
howDidTheyReachYouLabel.hint3: Enter the website link(s) used by the suspect or leave this blank if you don’t know.
howDidTheyReachYouLabel.hint4: Enter the names of the application(s) where you connected with the suspect or leave this blank if you don’t know.
howDidTheyReachYouLabel.hint5: For example: It came from an advertisement, a pop-up window, or some other way.
informationPage.intro: Help us learn more about what the suspect was after so that we can protect others from losing personal information.
informationPage.nextStep: Next: Details about what was affected
informationPage.tip: Report to <0>Equifax</0> and <1>TransUnion</1> to put an alert on your credit report.
informationPage.title: How was your personal information affected?
informationPage.typeOfInfoObtainedExampl: Select the type(s) of information taken.
informationPage.typeOfInfoReq: What information did they ask for?
informationPage.typeOfInfoReqExample: Select the type(s) of information requested.
landingPage.fullReport.description: Report an incident that has impacted you, someone you know, or a business.
landingPage.fyiReport.description: Provide general information about a scam or computer crime.
landingPage.intro: Your report helps the <0>Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP)</0> and the <1>Canadian Anti-Fraud Centre (CAFC)</1> learn more about these types of incidents.
landingPage.reportingOptions0: If you are in immediate danger, call
landingPage.reportingOptions1: If you are reporting the online sexual exploitation of children, report to <0>Cybertip.ca</0>.
landingPage.reportingOptions2: If you may have lost financial or personal information, you can try reporting to your financial institution and both credit bureaus: <0>Equifax</0> and <1>TransUnion</1>.
landingPage.reportingOptions3: If you encountered the incident online, you can also try reporting it to the website or app where it happened.
landingPage.title: Report a scam or computer crime
landingPage.warning: Reporting does not always lead to an investigation and we likely won’t be able to recover what was lost or damaged.
locationInfoForm.Warning: Enter a valid Canadian postal code in the format shown or leave this blank.

locationPage.title: Enter your location
locationinfoPage.skipInfo: If you’d rather not include your location, you can skip this step.

privacyConsentInfoForm.warning: Check the box to accept the terms of the Privacy statement.
privacyConsentInfoForm.yes: I accept the terms of the
privacyConsentInfoPage.learnMore: Learn more about who you’re reporting to and how your information is protected in the
privacyConsentInfoPage.sharing: The information you include in your report may also be shared with other police services and security partners to support investigations, intelligence analysis, and prevention efforts.
privacyConsentPage.intro: You are reporting to the RCMP’s <0>National Cybercrime Coordination Unit</0> and the <1>Canadian Anti-Fraud Centre</1>.
privacyConsentPage.title: Your privacy
privacyStatementPage.authorizationText1: The collection and use of your personal information by RCMP is authorized by the Royal Canadian Mounted Police Act, section 18.
privacyStatementPage.informationText1: You may choose to provide personal information or report anonymously. The personal information that you provide is retained in the <0>RCMP Personal Information Databank Operational Case Records (RCMP PPU 005)</0>.
privacyStatementPage.informationText2: Non-personally identifiable information may be shared with the <0>Canadian Digital Service</0> to improve this website.
privacyStatementPage.title: Privacy statement
privacyStatementPage.toinquireText1: If you have questions about your online report, you may contact the CAFC’s toll-free number at
privacyStatementPage.toinquireText2: To access and make requests to correct any of your personal information held by the RCMP, you may contact the RCMP’s Access to Information and Privacy Branch by email at <0>atipb@rcmp-grc.gc.ca</0> or by phone at
privacyStatementPage.toinquireText3: If you are concerned about how the RCMP handles your personal information, you may also contact the Office of the Privacy Commissioner of Canada by email at <0>info@priv.gc.ca</0> or by phone at
privacyStatementPage.webAnalyticsText1: Web analytics is the collection, analysis, and reporting of web traffic data (for example, the type of browser used, pages visited, links clicked). We use it to help improve this service to better serve you and other visitors. This site does not collect personally identifiable information, such as your IP address, through web analytics.
privacyStatementPage.webAnalyticsText2: This site carries out web analytics using services from a third-party service provider, Google Inc. (Google Analytics). <0>See the RCMP website's terms and conditions</0> for a full description of the web analytics we use.
privacyStatementPage.whathappensText: The NC3 and CAFC collect, review, and analyze reports to support investigations, trends analysis, public education, awareness, and prevention efforts. Reporting does not always lead to an investigation; police services have the discretion to investigate or not. Police do not open investigations for all reports. However, the information you provide can help law enforcement better understand these crimes and improve public education, awareness, and prevention efforts.
privacyStatementPage.whoText1: You are using a new website (currently in development) to report cybercrime and fraud incidents to the <0>National Cybercrime Coordination Unit (NC3)</0> and <1>Canadian Anti-Fraud Centre (CAFC)</1>.
privacyStatementPage.whoText2: The NC3 is a new national program at the <0>Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP)</0>. The NC3 works with the CAFC in coordinating law enforcement operations to fight cybercrime and fraud. The NC3 and CAFC may share information you include in your report with relevant police and security partners, such as the <1>Canadian Centre for Cybersecurity</1>, as needed.
startPage.intro: Gather all the information you can about the incident, such as:
startPage.requirement2: Suspect clues such as their contact information
startPage.requirement3: Details about what happened and how you were affected
startPage.title: Before you start
startPage.warning: You will not be able to save, edit, or return to your report once you start your submission. You can bookmark this page to start your report at another time.
suspectClues.intro: It’s often hard to tell who is behind a computer crime or scam. It’s okay if you don’t know much about the suspect. You can leave the questions you cannot answer blank.
suspectClues.question1: Who did they claim to be?
suspectClues.question1Details: Include any name, username, group, or organization mentioned by the suspect.
suspectClues.question2: Where did they ask you to send things?
suspectClues.question2Details: Include any addresses where the suspect  asked you to send money or information.
suspectClues.question3: What other details do you recall?
suspectClues.question3Details: Think about including any clues such as the time of day, the language they used to communicate, or any other detail that could help identify the suspect.
suspectClues.title: Add suspect clues
termsConditions.paragraph1: Your report will be assessed by the <0>Canadian Anti-Fraud Centre (CAFC)</0> and the <1>National Cybercrime Coordination Unit (NC3)</1>, a division of the <2>Royal Canadian Mounted Police (RCMP)</2>.
termsConditions.paragraph2: This service is subject to applicable <0>CAFC terms and conditions</0> and <1>RCMP terms and conditions</1>.
termsConditions.paragraph3: Learn more about who you’re reporting to and how your information is protected in the
termsConditions.title: Terms and conditions
thankYouPage.feedback: Have feedback to help us improve this site?
thankYouPage.feedback.new: Have more feedback to help us improve this site?
thankYouPage.feedback.success: Thank you. We have received your feedback.
thankYouPage.helpResource1: Learn about how you can protect yourself in the future.
thankYouPage.helpResource2: Stay up-to-date on what scams are most common.
thankYouPage.helpResource3: Find tips on how to prevent cybercrime.
thankYouPage.safelyCloseWindow: You can safely close this window
thankYouPage.summary: We’ve sent you a confirmation email.
thankYouPage.title: Thank you for reporting
thankYouPage.whatNextParagraph: We will analyze your report and combine it with others that are similar.
thankYouPage.whatNextParagraph2: Keep your reference number. You can use it to add more detail to your report by calling the Canadian Anti-Fraud Centre at
transactionDate.error.isFuture: Enter a date from the past.
whatHappenedPage.fyi.hint: Include things such as how you were contacted, what they asked for, and who they claimed to be.
whatHappenedPage.fyi.hint2: You can also include details like URLs, phone numbers, or email addresses you were contacted from.
whatHappenedPage.fyi.summary: Describe what happened, or what you saw
whatHappenedPage.fyi.title: Tell us about the scam or computer crime
whatHappenedPage.hint: Start at the beginning. Remember to include what they asked for, promised, stole, or threatened to do.
whatHappenedPage.intro1: What happened is not your fault. These crimes are not always easy to recognize and new ones are invented every day.
whatHappenedPage.thinkAbout: Think about including things such as:
whatHappenedPage.thinkAbout.business: What was the impact of the incident on your business?
whatHappenedPage.thinkAbout.default1: What was said or done for this to happen?
whatHappenedPage.thinkAbout.devices: How were your devices or accounts compromised?
whatHappenedPage.thinkAbout.money: How did they ask for and steal money?
whatHappenedPage.thinkAbout.other: What did they ask for, promise, or threaten to do?
whatHappenedPage.thinkAbout.personalInfo: How did they ask for and obtain information?
whatHappenedPage.title: What happened?
whatWasAffectedForm.business_assets.exam: For example: intellectual property, corporate systems, client information
whatWasAffectedForm.devices.example: For example: iPhone 7, social media accounts, wireless network
whatWasAffectedForm.financial.example: For example: bank account, credit card, cryptocurrency

whatWasAffectedForm.optionsHelpText: Select at least one thing that could potentially be affected as a result of this incident.
For example: date of birth, home address, social insurance number
whatWasAffectedForm.warning: Check at least one box. If you’re not sure, choose “Other”.
whatWasAffectedPage.intro: You’re likely not the only one affected by something like this. Help us learn more about what the suspect was after.
whatWasAffectedPage.title: What do you think could be affected?
whenDidItHappen.endBeforeStart: Start date must be before end date.
whenDidItHappenPage.dateRange.end.label: When did it last happen?
whenDidItHappenPage.intro: These incidents can happen once or multiple times. Tell us how often the suspect tried to contact you.

whenDidItHappenPage.question: How many times did the suspect contact you?
